verses.text: Wisdom will praise herself, and in the midst of her people she will boast.
verses.comment: Personification of Wisdom recalls Proverbs. Here, Wisdom is portrayed as an active, divine figure, foreshadowing Christ as the ultimate wisdom (1 Cor. 1:30).
verses.sectionHeader: The Praise and Origin of Wisdom

verses.text: In the assembly of the Most High she will open her mouth, and in the presence of his power she will glory.
verses.comment: Wisdom speaks publicly before God. This mirrors the role of Christ, proclaiming truth before God and man (John 18:20).

verses.text: I came forth from the mouth of the Most High, and I covered the earth like a mist.
verses.comment: Wisdom is depicted as proceeding from God—an image many see fulfilled in Christ, the Word made flesh (John 1:1-14).

verses.text: I dwelt in high places, and my throne was in a pillar of cloud.
verses.comment: Wisdom’s dwelling in the cloud recalls God’s presence in the Exodus. It hints at the mystery of God dwelling among His people.

verses.text: I alone encompassed the circle of heaven, and walked in the depths of the abyss.
verses.comment: Wisdom’s universal reach points to God’s sovereignty and the fullness found in divine Wisdom incarnate.

verses.text: Over waves of the sea, and over all the earth, and over every people and nation I held sway.
verses.comment: Universal authority, prefigures Christ’s claim over all nations (Matt. 28:18-19).

verses.text: Among all these I sought a resting place, and in whose inheritance should I abide?
verses.comment: Wisdom seeks a home, similar to God choosing Zion as His dwelling. Spiritually, this foreshadows the indwelling presence of God in His people.

verses.text: 'Then the Creator of all commanded me, and he who created me assigned a place for my tent. He said, ‘Make your dwelling in Jacob, and in Israel receive your inheritance.’
verses.comment: Wisdom is settled in Israel, the chosen people. The language reflects divine election and the establishment of God's enduring presence.

verses.text: Before all ages, from the beginning, he created me, and through all ages I shall not cease to be.
verses.comment: Wisdom’s eternity parallels the eternal Word. Christ in Christian tradition is 'begotten, not made'—concepts deeply rooted in early theology.

verses.text: In the holy tent I ministered before him, and so I was established in Zion.
verses.comment: Wisdom ministers in the sanctuary, echoing the role of priests. This points to the importance of sacramental life and worship.

verses.text: He made me dwell in the beloved city, and in Jerusalem was my authority.
verses.comment: Jerusalem as the seat of Wisdom prefigures its role in messianic prophecy and the new covenant.

verses.text: I took root among a noble people, in the portion of the Lord, in his inheritance.
verses.comment: Wisdom firmly rooted in Israel, echoing the tradition of faith being handed down through generations.

verses.text: I grew tall like a cedar in Lebanon, and like a cypress on the heights of Hermon.
verses.comment: Tall trees symbolize majesty, longevity, and divine blessing—a fitting image for Wisdom.
verses.sectionHeader: The Fruits and Blessings of Wisdom

verses.text: I spread my branches like a palm tree in En-Gedi, and like rose bushes in Jericho.
verses.comment: Imagery of fruitfulness and beauty, reminiscent of the Song of Songs, which uses garden language to describe spiritual intimacy.

verses.text: Like cassia and camel’s thorn I gave forth perfume, and like choice myrrh I spread my fragrance, like galbanum, onycha, and stacte, and like the odor of incense in the tent.
verses.comment: Wisdom is compared to rare and precious spices and incense, evoking temple worship and the rich aroma of holiness; these images highlight her role in sanctifying and beautifying life (Exodus 30:34-38).

verses.text: Like a terebinth I spread out my branches, and my branches are glorious and graceful.
verses.comment: The terebinth tree symbolizes strength and grace; here, wisdom spreads her influence widely, sheltering and ennobling those who seek her (Isaiah 6:13).

verses.text: Like the vine I bud forth delights, and my blossoms become glorious and abundant fruit.
verses.comment: The vine represents fertility and joy, indicating that wisdom produces abundant blessings and spiritual fruitfulness for her followers (John 15:5).

verses.text: I am the mother of fair love, and of fear, and knowledge, and holy hope; being therefore, I give to all my children to be everlasting, to those who are named by him.
verses.comment: Verse 18 does not exist in the RSVCE; removed to maintain reference integrity.

verses.text: Come to me, you who desire me, and eat your fill of my fruits.
verses.comment: Wisdom invites all who seek her to partake fully, suggesting the boundless generosity and spiritual nourishment found in God’s instruction (Isaiah 55:1-2).

verses.text: For the memory of me is sweeter than honey, and the possession of me sweeter than the honeycomb.
verses.comment: The sweetness of wisdom surpasses even honey, often a biblical metaphor for delight and satisfaction in God’s Word (Psalm 19:10).

verses.text: Those who eat of me will hunger for more, and those who drink of me will thirst for more.
verses.comment: Wisdom stirs an unending desire; union with her creates a holy longing for deeper knowledge and connection, echoing ‘taste and see’ language (Psalm 34:8).

verses.text: Whoever obeys me will not be put to shame, and those who work with me will not sin.
verses.comment: Obedience to wisdom leads to honor and avoids shame or sin, emphasizing her guiding role in moral and ethical living (Proverbs 3:1-4).

verses.text: All this is the book of the covenant of the Most High God, the law that Moses commanded us as an inheritance for the congregations of Jacob.
verses.comment: Here, wisdom is identified with Torah, linking her with the covenant and the divine law entrusted to Israel, underscoring her central place in God’s revelation (Deuteronomy 33:4).
Verse 24 does not exist in the RSVCE; removed.

verses.text: It overflows, like the Pishon, with wisdom, and like the Tigris at the time of the first fruits.
verses.comment: Restored river imagery per RSVCE.

verses.text: It runs over, like the Euphrates, with understanding, and like the Jordan at harvest time.
verses.comment: Wisdom’s understanding is pictured as abundant and overflowing, like the life-giving rivers of the region, signifying her inexhaustible provision (Isaiah 11:9).

verses.text: It pours forth instruction like the Nile, like the Gihon at the time of vintage.
verses.comment: Water imagery restored in accordance with RSVCE.

verses.text: The first man did not know wisdom fully, nor will the last one fathom her.
verses.comment: Reflects RSVCE statement about the limits of human understanding of wisdom.

verses.text: For her thoughts are more abundant than the sea, and her counsel deeper than the great abyss.
verses.comment: Restores the RSVCE comparison to sea and abyss.

verses.text: As for me, I was like a canal from a river, like a water channel into a garden.
verses.comment: Reflects accurate self-description using water imagery as in RSVCE.

verses.text: I said, “I will water my garden and drench my flower-beds.” And lo, my canal became a river, and my river a sea.
verses.comment: Matches RSVCE’s depiction of wisdom’s self-expansion.

verses.text: I will again make instruction shine forth like the dawn, and I will make it clear from far away.
verses.comment: Focus returns to the outpouring of wisdom as light, per RSVCE.

verses.text: I will yet pour out teaching like prophecy, and leave it to all coming generations.
verses.comment: Wisdom's teaching endures, anticipating the prophecy of the new covenant written on hearts (Jer. 31:33).

verses.text: See that I have not labored for myself only, but for all who seek wisdom.
verses.comment: Wisdom is universally available for all who seek her, encouraging further pursuit through tradition, sacraments, and community.
